titleStmt.title: A Guide to the United States’ History of Recognition, Diplomatic, and Consular Relations, by Country, since 1776: Korea
Korea

sourceDesc.p: Researched and written by Christopher Morrison, August 2011

div.head: Recognition, 1882.
div.p: The United States and the Kingdom of Choson (Korea) engaged in their first official diplomatic interaction on May 22, 1882, when representatives of the two states signed a treaty of amity and commerce at Chemulpo, Korea. The treaty had been negotiated with the assistance of Chinese officials, since China had for many years had influence in Korea’s foreign affairs due to a historical tributary relationship between the two countries. In fact, Korea was an independent state and this fact was acknowledged in the treaty. It was the first treaty Korea signed with a Western nation.

div.head: Establishment of Diplomatic Relations and Legation in Korea, 1883.
div.p: Diplomatic relations and the American Legation at Seoul were established on May 20, 1883, when Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary Lucius H. Foote presented his credentials to the King of Korea.

div.head: Diplomatic Relations Ended, 1905.
div.p: Japan assumed direction of Korean foreign relations on November 17, 1905, and U.S. Envoy Edwin Morgan closed the Legation on November 28, 1905.
